TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit RemotingConfiguration extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides various static methods for configuring the remoting infrastructure.

MemberSignature.Value: public static string ApplicationId { get; }
.property string ApplicationId

Docs.summary: Gets the ID of the currently executing application.
Docs.value: A <see cref="T:System.String"> that contains the ID of the currently executing application.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The application ID is prepended to the URI of the objects created by the currently executing application.

MemberSignature.Value: public static string ApplicationName { get; set; }
.property string ApplicationName

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of a remoting application.
Docs.value: The name of a remoting application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks An application name can be set only once, either through the current property or through a configuration file. If an application is running inside a hosted environment, such as Internet Information Services (IIS), this value might have already been set (usually to the virtual directory). The current property will return `null` if the application name has not been set.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the ApplicationName property to indicate the name of the remoting application. For the full example code, see examples for the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> and <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownServiceType%2A> methods.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#2](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#2)]
The following code example demonstrates how to access an object remoted from a named application.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#6](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#6)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void Configure (string filename);
.method public static hidebysig void Configure(string filename) cil managed

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("Use System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.Configure(string fileName, bool ensureSecurity) instead.", false)

Docs.param: The name of the remoting configuration file. Can be `null`.
Docs.summary: Reads the configuration file and configures the remoting infrastructure. Configure is obsolete. Please use <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.Configure%28System.String%2CSystem.Boolean%29> instead.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > Configure is obsolete. Please use <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.Configure%28System.String%2CSystem.Boolean%29> instead.
Passing `null` as the parameter will cause default remoting initialization without requiring the existence of a configuration file.
For configuration file syntax, see [Remoting Settings Schema](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/dc2d1e62-9af7-4ca1-99fd-98b93bb4db9e).
> [!NOTE] > Marshal-by-reference objects (MBRs) do not reside in memory forever. Instead, unless the type overrides <xref:System.MarshalByRefObject.InitializeLifetimeService%2A?displayProperty=fullName> to control its own lifetime policies, each MBR has a finite lifetime before the .NET Framework remoting system begins the process of deleting it and reclaiming the memory. For more information, see [Lifetime Leases](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/c72d561c-1266-4c8b-b258-2c168c08da9a).
## Examples [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration_Configure_Client#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration_Configure_Client#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void Configure (string filename, bool ensureSecurity);
.method public static hidebysig void Configure(string filename, bool ensureSecurity) cil managed

Docs.param: The name of the remoting configuration file. Can be `null`.
If set to `true` security is required. If set to `false`, security is not required but still may be used.
Docs.summary: Reads the configuration file and configures the remoting infrastructure.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Passing `null` as the parameter will cause default remoting initialization without requiring the existence of a configuration file. For more information about remoting and security see [Security in Remoting.](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/9574262c-d4b1-41c5-8600-24ff147c0add)
For configuration file syntax, see [Remoting Settings Schema](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/dc2d1e62-9af7-4ca1-99fd-98b93bb4db9e).
> [!NOTE] > Marshal-by-reference objects (MBRs) do not reside in memory forever. Instead, unless the type overrides <xref:System.MarshalByRefObject.InitializeLifetimeService%2A?displayProperty=fullName> to control its own lifetime policies, each MBR has a finite lifetime before the .NET Framework remoting system begins the process of deleting it and reclaiming the memory. For more information, see [Lifetime Leases](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/c72d561c-1266-4c8b-b258-2c168c08da9a).

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool CustomErrorsEnabled (bool isLocalRequest);
.method public static hidebysig bool CustomErrorsEnabled(bool isLocalRequest) cil managed

Docs.param: `true` to specify local callers; `false` to specify remote callers.
Docs.summary: Indicates whether the server channels in this application domain return filtered or complete exception information to local or remote callers.
Docs.returns: `true` if only filtered exception information is returned to local or remote callers, as specified by the parameter; `false` if complete exception information is returned.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Complete exception information includes the exact server exception and the server stack trace. Filtered information includes a standard remoting exception but no server stack trace.
The `CustomErrorsEnabled` method reflects configuration settings that were specified in the `mode` attribute of the `<customErrors>` element of the application configuration file. For more information about configuration options, see [[\<topic://cpconconfiguration>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/92c0c097-d984-4315-835b-7490ecdf1097).
The following table shows the three server channel property values that specify which callers receive exception information and what type of information they receive.
|Value|Description| |-----------|-----------------| |`off`|All callers receive complete exception information.| |`on`|All callers receive filtered exception information.| |`remoteOnly`|Local callers receive complete exception information; remote callers receive filtered exception information.|
The following table shows the interaction of the parameter and the server channel property.
|Value|isLocalRequest|Return value|Description| |-----------|--------------------|------------------|-----------------| |`on`|`true`|`true`|Local callers receive filtered exception information.| |`on`|`false`|`true`|Remote callers receive filtered exception information.| |`off`|`true`|`false`|Local callers receive complete exception information.| |`off`|`false`|`false`|Remote callers receive complete exception information.| |`remoteOnly`|`true`|`false`|Local callers receive complete exception information.| |`remoteOnly`|`false`|`true`|Remote callers receive filtered exception information.|
For information about using application configuration files to control the return of exception information to callers, see the `<customErrors>` element.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Runtime.Remoting.CustomErrorsModes CustomErrorsMode { get; set; }
.property valuetype System.Runtime.Remoting.CustomErrorsModes CustomErrorsMode

Docs.summary: Gets or sets value that indicates how custom errors are handled.
Docs.value: A member of the <see cref="T:System.Runtime.Remoting.CustomErrorsModes"> enumeration that indicates how custom errors are handled.

Docs.returns: An array of object types registered on the client as types that will be activated remotely.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a).

.method public static hidebysig class System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedServiceTypeEntry[] GetRegisteredActivatedServiceTypes() cil managed

Docs.summary: Retrieves an array of object types registered on the service end that can be activated on request from a client.
Docs.returns: An array of object types registered on the service end that can be activated on request from a client.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a).

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry[] GetRegisteredWellKnownClientTypes ();
.method public static hidebysig class System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry[] GetRegisteredWellKnownClientTypes() cil managed

Docs.summary: Retrieves an array of object types registered on the client end as well-known types.
Docs.returns: An array of object types registered on the client end as well-known types.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Well-known object types can be either single call or singleton. If an object type is single call, then a new instance of it is created each time a call from the client comes in. All calls to a singleton object are handled by one instance of that object.
For a more detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).
## Examples [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration_GetRegisteredWellKnownClient_Client#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration_GetRegisteredWellKnownClient_Client#1)]

.method public static hidebysig class System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownServiceTypeEntry[] GetRegisteredWellKnownServiceTypes() cil managed

Docs.summary: Retrieves an array of object types registered on the service end as well-known types.
Docs.returns: An array of object types registered on the service end as well-known types.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Well-known object types can be either single call or singleton. If an object type is single call, then a new instance of it is created each time a call from the client comes in. All calls to a singleton object are handled by one instance of that object.
For a more detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).

MemberSignature.Value: public static string ProcessId { get; }

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterActivatedClientType (System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedClientTypeEntry entry);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterActivatedClientType(class System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedClientTypeEntry entry) cil managed

Docs.param: Configuration settings for the client-activated type.
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> recorded in the provided <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedClientTypeEntry> on the client end as a type that can be activated on the server.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an instance of a client-activated object on the server, you must know its <xref:System.Type> and it must be registered on the server end by using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedServiceType%2A> method. To obtain a proxy for a new instance of the client-activated object, the client must first register a channel with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices> and then activate the object by calling `new`.
To activate a client-activated object type with the `new` keyword, you must first register the object type on the client end using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote application where `new` attempts to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to create a new instance of the client-activated object, you must supply the remote application's URL as a parameter, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary. To supply the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method with the URL of the server where you want to create the object, you must encapsulate the URL in an instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Activation.UrlAttribute> class.
For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a).

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterActivatedClientType (Type type, string appUrl);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterActivatedClientType(class System.Type type, string appUrl) cil managed

Docs.param: The object <see cref="T:System.Type">.
URL of the application where this type is activated.
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> on the client end as a type that can be activated on the server, using the given parameters to initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedClientTypeEntry> class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an instance of a client-activated object on the server, you must know its <xref:System.Type> and it must be registered on the server end by using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedServiceType%2A> method. To obtain a proxy for a new instance of the client-activated object, the client must first register a channel with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices> and then activate the object by calling `new`.
To activate a client-activated object type with the `new` keyword, you must first register the object type on the client end using the RegisterActivatedClientType method. Calling the RegisterActivatedClientType method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote application where `new` attempts to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to create a new instance of the client-activated object, you must supply the remote application's URL as a parameter, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary. To supply the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method with the URL of the server where you want to create the object, you must encapsulate the URL in an instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Activation.UrlAttribute> class.
For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a)
## Examples The following code example demonstrates registration of an object type on the client end as a type that can be activated on the server. For the server code that corresponds to the presented client code, see the example for the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedServiceType%2A> method.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterActivatedServiceType (System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedServiceTypeEntry entry);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterActivatedServiceType(class System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedServiceTypeEntry entry) cil managed

Docs.param: Configuration settings for the client-activated type.
Docs.summary: Registers an object type recorded in the provided <see cref="T:System.Runtime.Remoting.ActivatedServiceTypeEntry"> on the service end as one that can be activated on request from a client.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an instance of a client-activated object on the server, you must know its <xref:System.Type> and it must be registered on the server end by using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedServiceType%2A> method. To obtain a proxy for a new instance of the client-activated object, the client must first register a channel with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices> and then activate the object by calling `new` or <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
To activate a client-activated object type with the `new` keyword, you must first register the object type on the client end using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote application, where `new` attempts to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A> method to create a new instance of the client-activated object, you must supply the remote application's URL as a parameter, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary. To supply the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A> method with the URL of the server where you want to create the object, you must encapsulate the URL in an instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Activation.UrlAttribute> class.
For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a).

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterActivatedServiceType (Type type);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterActivatedServiceType(class System.Type type) cil managed

Docs.param: The <see cref="T:System.Type"> of object to register.
Docs.summary: Registers a specified object type on the service end as a type that can be activated on request from a client.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an instance of a client-activated object on the server, you must know its <xref:System.Type> and it must be registered on the server end by using the RegisterActivatedServiceType method. To obtain a proxy for a new instance of the client-activated object, the client must first register a channel with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices> and then activate the object by calling `new` or <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
To activate a client-activated object type with the `new` keyword, you must first register the object type on the client end using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote application, where `new` attempts to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A> method to create a new instance of the client-activated object, you must supply the remote application's URL as a parameter, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary. To supply the <xref:System.Activator.CreateInstance%2A> method with the URL of the server where you want to create the object, you must encapsulate the URL in an instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Activation.UrlAttribute> class.
For a detailed description of client-activated objects, see [[\<topic://cpconClientActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/4a791494-c18a-4711-a5c1-4ab0e49a8f1a).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates registration of an object type on the server as a type that can be activated by the client. For the client code that corresponds to the presented server code, see the example for the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterActivatedClientType%2A> method.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#2](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#2)]
The following code example shows the service object registered in the sample code above.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#3](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ClientActivation#3)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterWellKnownClientType (System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry entry);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterWellKnownClientType(class System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry entry) cil managed

Docs.param: Configuration settings for the well-known type.
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> recorded in the provided <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry> on the client end as a well-known type that can be activated on the server.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Any client that knows the URI of a registered well-known object can obtain a proxy for the object by registering the channel it prefers with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices>, and activating the object by calling `new` or <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName>. To activate a well-known object with `new`, you must first register the well-known object type on the client using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote object, which allows the `new` keyword to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to activate the well-known object, you must supply it with the object's URL as an argument, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary.
For a detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterWellKnownClientType (Type type, string objectUrl);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterWellKnownClientType(class System.Type type, string objectUrl) cil managed

Docs.param: The object <see cref="T:System.Type">.
URL of a well-known client object.
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> on the client end as a well-known type that can be activated on the server, using the given parameters to initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownClientTypeEntry> class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Any client that knows the URI of a registered well-known object can obtain a proxy for the object by registering the channel it prefers with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices>, and activating the object by calling `new` or <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName>. To activate a well-known object with `new`, you must first register the well-known object type on the client using the RegisterWellKnownClientType method. Calling the RegisterWellKnownClientType method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote object, which allows the `new` keyword to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to activate the well-known object, you must supply it with the object's URL as an argument, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary.
For a detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates registration of an object type on the client end as a well-known type. For the server code that corresponds to the presented client code, see the example for the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownServiceType%2A> method.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#5](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#5)] [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#6](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#6)] [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#7](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#7)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterWellKnownServiceType (System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownServiceTypeEntry entry);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterWellKnownServiceType(class System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownServiceTypeEntry entry) cil managed

Docs.param: Configuration settings for the well-known type.
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> recorded in the provided <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownServiceTypeEntry> on the service end as a well-known type.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Any client that knows the URI of a registered well-known object can obtain a proxy for the object by registering the channel it prefers with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices>, and activating the object by calling `new` or the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method. To activate a well-known object with `new`, you must first register the well-known object type on the client using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote object, which allows the `new` keyword to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to activate the well-known object, you must supply it with the object's URL as an argument, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary.
When the call arrives at the server, the .NET Framework extracts the URI from the message, examines the remoting tables to locate the reference for the object that matches the URI, and then instantiates the object if necessary, forwarding the method call to the object. If the object is registered as <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownObjectMode>, it is destroyed after the method call is completed. A new instance of the object is created for each method called. The only difference between <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and `new` is that the former allows you to specify a URL as a parameter, and the latter obtains the URL from the configuration.
The remote object itself is not instantiated by the registration process. This only happens when a client attempts to call a method on the object or activates the object from the client side.
For a detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).
## Examples [!CODE [CreateObjRef2#2](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/CreateObjRef2#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RegisterWellKnownServiceType (Type type, string objectUri, System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownObjectMode mode);
.method public static hidebysig void RegisterWellKnownServiceType(class System.Type type, string objectUri, valuetype System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownObjectMode mode) cil managed

Docs.param: The object <see cref="T:System.Type">.
The object URI.
The activation mode of the well-known object type being registered. (See <see cref="T:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownObjectMode">.)
Docs.summary: Registers an object <see cref="T:System.Type"> on the service end as a well-known type, using the given parameters to initialize a new instance of <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownServiceTypeEntry>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Any client that knows the URI of a registered well-known object can obtain a proxy for the object by registering the channel it prefers with <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.Channels.ChannelServices>, and activating the object by calling `new` or the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method. To activate a well-known object with `new`, you must first register the well-known object type on the client using the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method. Calling the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method gives the remoting infrastructure the location of the remote object, which allows the `new` keyword to create it. If, on the other hand, you use the <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to activate the well-known object, you must supply it with the object's URL as an argument, so no prior registration on the client end is necessary.
When the call arrives at the server, the .NET Framework extracts the URI from the message, examines the remoting tables to locate the reference for the object that matches the URI, and then instantiates the object if necessary, forwarding the method call to the object. If the object is registered as <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.WellKnownObjectMode>, it is destroyed after the method call is completed. A new instance of the object is created for each method called. The only difference between <xref:System.Activator.GetObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and `new` is that the former allows you to specify a URL as a parameter, and the latter obtains the URL from the configuration.
The remote object itself is not instantiated by the registration process. This only happens when a client attempts to call a method on the object or activates the object from the client side.
For a detailed description of well-known objects, see [[\<topic://cpconServerActivation>]](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/77ded6e2-4ca8-448b-acf2-562d27fd4396).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates registration of an object type on the server as a well-known object type. For the client code that corresponds to the presented server code, see the example for the <xref:System.Runtime.Remoting.RemotingConfiguration.RegisterWellKnownClientType%2A> method.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#1](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#1)] [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#2](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#2)] [!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#3](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#3)]
The following code example shows the service object registered in the sample code above.
[!CODE [RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#4](../CodeSnippet/VS_Snippets_Remoting/RemotingConfiguration.ServerActivation1#4)]
